claim: All of Snow White's dwarfs can play a game of 7 Wonders simultaneously.

supporting.text: Snow White's dwarfs are fictional characters and cannot physically interact with real-world board games.

attacks.text: Snow White's dwarfs are fictional characters and cannot physically interact with real-world board games.
The claim is about fictional interaction, not physical reality, so fictional characters can logically 'play' in their universe.
Fictional universes often follow real-world rules unless specified otherwise, making physical interaction impossible by default.
Many board games exist in fictional universes (e.g., Wizard's Chess in Harry Potter), establishing precedent for game-playing.

supporting.text: 7 Wonders is a modern board game that did not exist during the time period in which Snow White's story is set.

attacks.text: 7 Wonders is a modern board game that did not exist during the time period in which Snow White's story is set.
Snow White's dwarfs are fictional characters, and their story can be adapted to include modern elements like board games.
The original Snow White story is a fairy tale with no room for modern adaptations without breaking its historical context.

supporting.text: The dwarfs are typically depicted as miners with no shown interest or ability in playing complex strategy games.

attacks.text: The dwarfs are typically depicted as miners with no shown interest or ability in playing complex strategy games.
The dwarfs are intelligent and cooperative, as shown by their ability to work together in mining and household tasks, which suggests they could learn and play a strategy game.
There is no canonical evidence that the dwarfs have ever engaged in or learned complex strategy games, making their ability to play 7 Wonders speculative.
The dwarfs' names and personalities in some adaptations suggest diverse skills, which could include strategic thinking or gaming.

supporting.text: The number of dwarfs (7) matches the number of players in 7 Wonders, but this is coincidental and not evidence of capability.

attacks.text: The number of dwarfs (7) matches the number of players in 7 Wonders, but this is coincidental and not evidence of capability.
The dwarfs are fictional characters, so they cannot physically play any game.
In the context of the story, the dwarfs are depicted as capable of performing complex tasks like mining, suggesting they could learn to play a game.
7 Wonders requires reading and strategic thinking, which the dwarfs are not shown to possess in the original fairy tale.
Modern adaptations of Snow White sometimes portray the dwarfs with more human-like intelligence and skills, making it plausible they could play board games.
